importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the sexual assault at Gettysburg College occurred, marking the beginning of a long legal and emotional journey for the victim.
The year when Ian Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you' to Shannon Keeler, reigniting her efforts to pursue legal action.
The year when Keeler shared her experience in an Associated Press story highlighting the reluctance of prosecutors to pursue campus sexual assault cases.
The date Cleary was detained in Metz, France, on a vagrancy-related charge, which led to his eventual extradition to Pennsylvania.
The date of the sentencing in court, when Ian Cleary was sentenced to two to four years in prison.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The three-year period during which Keeler pursued her case after public exposure in 2021 and Cleary was eventually extradited in 2024.
The period spanning from the initial assault to the final sentencing, highlighting a decade-long struggle for justice and accountability.
The 11-year gap between the assault and the eventual prosecution, illustrating the systemic failure in addressing campus sexual violence.

keyTakeAways: The case underscores a broader issue in the justice system: the difficulty of prosecuting campus sexual assault cases, especially when evidence is lost and time passes.
The victim, Shannon Keeler, spent over a decade pursuing justice, only to have her case revived due to public awareness and media exposure.
Ian Cleary, who committed the assault in 2013, sent a message saying 'So I raped you' in 2019, which became a catalyst for renewed legal action.
Despite a guilty plea, Cleary received a sentence below state guidelines due to remorse and mental health issues, raising questions about proportionality.
The case highlights the failure of institutions to protect victims and the long-term psychological impact on survivors.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is central to the narrative, representing the long-term trauma of survivors and the systemic failures in campus justice systems that allow such crimes to go unpunished for years.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In 2013, Ian Cleary sexually assaulted Shannon Keeler at Gettysburg College, an incident that went unprosecuted for over a decade. Keeler, who first reported it shortly after, faced years of legal and emotional struggle, with prosecutors reluctant to act. In 2019, Cleary sent a Facebook message saying 'So I raped you,' which reinvigorated her efforts. After a three-year search, Cleary was extradited from France in 2024, and on October 20, 2025, he was sentenced to two to four years in prison by Senior Judge Kevin Hess. The sentence, below state guidelines, was based on Cleary’s guilty plea, remorse, and history of mental illness. The case exposes systemic failures in campus sexual assault justice, including evidence destruction, prosecutorial inaction, and delayed accountability, while also highlighting the enduring trauma of survivors like Keeler, who described the 12-year journey as surreal and painful.
title: Man Sentenced to Prison After Facebook Message Acknowledging 2013 Campus Rape
